questions.title: Capital Investments and Capital Allocation
questions.question: When preparing the cash-flow forecasts for both projects, Soroka should include:

choices.A: only the cost of the market research.
choices.B: only the loss of revenue from existing products.
choices.C: both the market research cost and the loss of revenue from existing products.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Capital allocation analysis should include only incremental cash flows associated with a new investment. The loss of revenue from existing products is an incremental negative effect that should be included in the analysis. The market research costs in this case are a sunk cost because the research has already been completed and therefore does not affect cash-flow estimates, no matter whether ABC undertakes either of these projects or neither of them.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Capital allocation analysis should include only incremental cash flows associated with a new investment. The loss of revenue from existing products is an incremental negative effect that should be included in the analysis. The market research costs in this case are a sunk cost because the research has already been completed and therefore does not affect cash-flow estimates, no matter whether ABC undertakes either of these projects or neither of them.

questions.title: Capital Investments and Capital Allocation
questions.question:
An electric vehicle manufacturer invests in a new technology to meet new safety standards. This project is best classified as a(n):

  1. expansion project.
  2. compliance project.
  3. going concern project.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because expansion projects are those that increase business size, usually by investing in the development of new products or services and/or acquiring other companies. The investment in new technology to meet improved safety standards is not an expansion project. Correct because regulatory and compliance projects are required by third parties, such as government regulatory bodies, to meet safety and regulatory compliance standards. The investment in new technology to meet improved safety standards is therefore a compliance project. Incorrect because going concern projects are those investments needed to continue the company‚Äôs current operations and maintain the existing size of the business. The investment in new technology to meet improved safety standards is not a going concern project. Capital Investments and Capital Allocation describe types of capital investments
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because expansion projects are those that increase business size, usually by investing in the development of new products or services and/or acquiring other companies. The investment in new technology to meet improved safety standards is not an expansion project.

  2. Correct because regulatory and compliance projects are required by third parties, such as government regulatory bodies, to meet safety and regulatory compliance standards. The investment in new technology to meet improved safety standards is therefore a compliance project.

  3. Incorrect because going concern projects are those investments needed to continue the company‚Äôs current operations and maintain the existing size of the business. The investment in new technology to meet improved safety standards is not a going concern project.

questions.question: The most likely impact from the cash-flow timing considered by Soroka is that:

choices.A: both IRR and NPV would decrease.
choices.B: both IRR and NPV stay unchanged.
choices.C: only IRR would decrease but NPV would increase.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The forecasted timing of cash flow is an important factor affecting both projects‚Äô IRR and NPV. In the case of delaying all future cash flows from both projects by six months, the result would be a lower IRR and a lower NPV. Given that all future cash flows are to be received six months later, their present value decreases; hence, the NPV and IRR of an entire project also decrease. B is incorrect because when cash flows from the investment projects are delayed by six months, both projects‚Äô NPV and IRR would decrease, not stay unchanged. C is incorrect because when cash flows from the investment projects are delayed by six months, both project‚Äôs NPV and IRR would decrease.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The forecasted timing of cash flow is an important factor affecting both projects‚Äô IRR and NPV. In the case of delaying all future cash flows from both projects by six months, the result would be a lower IRR and a lower NPV. Given that all future cash flows are to be received six months later, their present value decreases; hence, the NPV and IRR of an entire project also decrease.

B is incorrect because when cash flows from the investment projects are delayed by six months, both projects‚Äô NPV and IRR would decrease, not stay unchanged.

C is incorrect because when cash flows from the investment projects are delayed by six months, both project‚Äôs NPV and IRR would decrease.

  1. prefer Project 1.
  2. prefer Project 2.
  3. be indifferent between Project 1 and Project 2.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because when the choice is between two mutually exclusive projects and the NPV and IRR rank the two projects differently, the NPV criterion is strongly preferred. As a practical matter, once a corporation has the data to calculate the NPV, it is fairly trivial to then calculate the IRR and other capital allocation criteria. However, the most appropriate and theoretically sound criterion is the NPV. Incorrect because when the choice is between two mutually exclusive projects and the NPV and IRR rank the two projects differently, the NPV (not IRR)¬†criterion is strongly preferred. Incorrect because when the choice is between two mutually exclusive projects and the NPV and IRR rank the two projects differently, the NPV criterion (not either one) is strongly preferred. Capital Investments and Capital Allocation describe the capital allocation process, calculate net present value (NPV), internal rate of return (IRR), and return on invested capital (ROIC), and contrast their use in capital allocation

Solution

  1. Correct because when the choice is between two mutually exclusive projects and the NPV and IRR rank the two projects differently, the NPV criterion is strongly preferred. As a practical matter, once a corporation has the data to calculate the NPV, it is fairly trivial to then calculate the IRR and other capital allocation criteria. However, the most appropriate and theoretically sound criterion is the NPV.

  2. Incorrect because when the choice is between two mutually exclusive projects and the NPV and IRR rank the two projects differently, the NPV (not IRR)¬†criterion is strongly preferred.

  3. Incorrect because when the choice is between two mutually exclusive projects and the NPV and IRR rank the two projects differently, the NPV criterion (not either one) is strongly preferred.

questions.title: Capital Investments and Capital Allocation
questions.question:
Which of the following is considered a capital allocation pitfall? Basing investment decisions on:

  1. opportunity costs.
  2. after-tax cash flows.
  3. short-run accounting numbers.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because not identifying the economic alternatives (real and financial) that are the opportunity costs is probably the biggest failure by companies in their analyses. Basing investments decisions on opportunity costs is the correct approach and hence not a capital allocation pitfall. Incorrect because one of the capital allocation assumptions is that decisions must reflect the impact of taxes. Furthermore, in analyzing a complicated investment, individuals assessing the investment for the company may erroneously omit relevant cash flows, double-count cash flows, and mishandle taxes. Basing investments decisions on after-tax cash flows is the correct approach and hence not a capital allocation pitfall. Correct because one common pitfall is basing investment decisions on EPS, net income, or ROE: Companies sometimes have incentives to boost earnings per share, net income, or return on equity. Many investments, even those with strong NPVs, do not increase these accounting numbers in the short run and may even reduce them. Paying too much attention to short-run accounting numbers can result in a company choosing investments that are not in the long-run economic interests of its shareholders. Capital Investments and Capital Allocation describe principles of capital allocation and common capital allocation pitfalls

questions.title: Capital Investments and Capital Allocation
questions.question:
A company should exercise the abandonment option on an investment if the present value of the cash flows from continuing the investment is:

  1. lower than the cash flow from abandoning the investment.
  2. the same as the cash flow from abandoning the investment.
  3. greater than the cash flow from abandoning the investment.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because if the cash flow from abandoning an investment exceeds the present value of the cash flows from continuing the investment, the company should exercise the abandonment option. Conversely, if the the PV of the cash flows from continuing the investment is lower than the cash flow from abandoning the investment, the company should exercise the abandonment option. Incorrect because if the cash flow from abandoning an investment exceeds the present value of the cash flows from continuing the investment (and not when it is equal to), the company should exercise the abandonment option. Incorrect because if the cash flow from abandoning an investment exceeds the present value of the cash flows from continuing the investment, the company should exercise the abandonment option. The the PV of the cash flows from continuing the investment is greater than the cash flow from abandoning the investment, the company should not exercise the abandonment option. questions.title: Capital Investments and Capital Allocation
questions.question:
Subsequent to making a capital investment, a company reacts to poor financial results from the project by abandoning it. This action alone best exemplifies the exercise of a:

  1. sizing option.
  2. timing option.
  3. flexibility option.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because sizing options encompass abandonment or expansion of capacity. If after investing the company can abandon the investment if the financial results are disappointing, it has an abandonment option. At some future date, if the cash flow from abandoning an investment exceeds the present value of the cash flows from continuing the investment, the company should exercise the abandonment option. Conversely, if the company can make additional investments when future financial results are strong, the company has a growth option or an expansion option. Incorrect because timing options involve the sequencing of projects. Instead of investing now, the company can delay investing. Delaying an investment and basing the decision on hopefully improved information that you might have in, say, a year could help improve the NPV of the projects selected. Project sequencing options allow the company to defer the decision to invest in a future investment until the outcome of some or all of a current investment is known. Investments are sequenced over time, so that investing in a project creates the option to make future investments. Incorrect because flexibility options include operational changes possible with current capacity, such as paying overtime or adding a shift to meet excess demand. Once an investment is made, operational flexibilities besides abandonment or expansion may be available. If demand exceeds capacity, by increasing prices, the company could benefit from the excess demand, which it cannot do by increasing production. There are also production-flexibility options, which offer the operational flexibility to alter production when demand varies from what is forecast. Even though it is expensive, the company can profit from working overtime or from adding additional shifts. Capital Investments and Capital Allocation describe types of real options relevant to capital investments
